To reduce the negative climate impacts from burning fossil fuels, the Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, today announced the Government of Canadaâ€™s intention to develop a clean fuel standard as part of the governmentâ€™s made in Canada plan to fight climate change.

caption_original:
The magnificent Ferruginous Hawk, with a wingspan that can reach 1.5 m, is one of the largest species of hawks. Once found widely across the prairie provinces, its population has declined by almost two-thirds since 1992 due largely to habitat loss! Today, this majestic bird is listed as threatened under the Species at Risk Act.

To help give ferruginous hawks and other wildlife species a chance to thrive, Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with Nature Conservancy of Canada to conserve more than 1,200 hectares of prairie grassland in Alberta's Porcupine Hills region. This land will be protected in perpetuity under the Government of Canadaâ€™s Ecological Gifts Program. http://ow.ly/vk9F3060ACR

This land will be protected in perpetuity under the Government of Canadaâ€™s Ecological Gifts Program.

Did you know that Areas of Concern are regions within the Great Lakes that have experienced high levels of environmental harm? Of the 17 Areas of Concern located entirely within Canadian waters or on channels connecting the lakes, 3 areas (Collingwood Harbour, Severn Sound and Wheatley Harbour) are considered fully restored and 2 areas (Jackfish Bay and Spanish Harbour) are in recovery. 

Check out their progress!  #Indicators #Sustainability http://ow.ly/t9ei306BnLj

caption_original:
Each year, thousands of shorebirds and waterfowl can be seen on the beaches and lagoons of Miscou Island, off the coast of New Brunswick, during their fall migration. The Government of Canada is pleased to partner with Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect an additional 47 hectares of this ecologically-sensitive wetlands habitat.

By protecting the lands from development, this area will continue to serve as an important refuge for migratory birds such as the Piping Plover, listed as endangered under the Species at Risk Act. 

Conserving coastal lands like these also benefits local communities by helping to mitigate the impacts of storms and rising sea levels associated with climate change. http://ow.ly/2cYz306wOnw

By protecting the lands from development, this area will continue to serve as an important refuge for migratory birds such as the Piping Plover, listed as endangered under the Species at Risk Act. When it comes to connecting with nature, it also means taking care of it! Science shows that triclosan, a chemical used as an antimicrobial ingredient, can cause harm to aquatic organisms, like plants and fish. The harm happens when products that contain this substance are washed down household drains and then released into water. 

Get the scoop on what the Government of Canada is doing to address this issue! http://ow.ly/dSfy306wU1J

Have you heard of the EcoAction Community Funding Program? Since 1995, Environment and Climate Change Canada has provided to community-based, non-profit organizations financial support for projects that have measurable and positive impacts on the environment. 

This Funding Program supports projects that address the following four themes: climate change, clean air, clean water and nature. 

For more information about this Program and how to apply, just visit the EcoAction Community Funding Program website. You have until December 12 to apply! http://ow.ly/agr7306uRs0

caption_original:
What do microwave radiation and old roller blades have in common? 

Dr. Tyler Stephenson at the University of Calgary is using both to help his research related to oil viscosity. The heat from the microwaves and spinning of the roller blades helps to heat the inside of the pipes more efficiently, and forms a layer of protection against wax buildup and corrosion. Now you know!

Now you know!
